Graphical abstract This review comprehensively explores the potential of ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents as electrolytes in lithium batteries such as lithium-ion batteries, lithium-oxygen batteries, and lithium-sulfur batteries. The rising need for efficient and sustainable energy storage systems has led to increased interest in the use of advanced electrolytes consisting of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) and ionic liquids (ILs). These electrolytes are appealing candidates for supercapacitors, next-generation lithium-ion batteries, and different energy storage systems because of their special features including non-flammability, low volatility, low-toxicity, good electrochemical stability, and good thermal and chemical stability. This review explores the advantages of the proposed electrolytes by examining their potential to address the critical challenges in lithium battery technology, including safety concerns, energy density limitations, and operational stability. To achieve this, a comprehensive overview of the lithium salts commonly employed in rechargeable lithium battery electrolytes is presented. Moreover, key physicochemical and functional attributes of ILs and DESs, such as electrochemical stability, ionic conductivity, nonflammability, and viscosity are also discussed with a focus on how these features impact battery performance. The integration of lithium salts with ILs and DESs in modern lithium battery technologies, including lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries, lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries, and lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, are further examined in the study. Various electrochemical performance metrics including cycling stability, charge/discharge profiles, retention capacity and battery’s coulombic efficiency (CE) are also analyzed for the above-mentioned systems. By summarizing recent advances and challenges, this review also highlights the potential of electrolytes consisting of DESs and ILs to enhance energy density, durability, and safety in future energy storage applications. Additionally future research directions, including the molecular optimization of ILs and DESs, optimizing lithium salt compositions, and developing scalable synthesis methods to accelerate their practical implementation in next-generation energy storage applications are also explored. Keywords Electrolytes Deep eutectic solvents Ionic liquids Lithium salts Electrochemical performance Lithium batteries 1 Introduction The fast advancement and growing need for high-performance, lightweight, and affordable portable electronics, such as those used in electric cars, aeronautics, and healthcare industries, has encouraged researchers to investigate enhanced electrochemical energy storage (EES) technologies [1,2]. In the pursuit of renewable energy options, there is an urgent need for the development of long-lasting, highly effective, high energy-power resources. Different EES systems, including batteries and supercapacitors, have emerged as appealing candidates to meet these demands. Batteries shine with their high energy density and high-rate capability, whereas supercapacitors provide advantages such as quick charge-discharge rates, high power output, and extended cycle life [3,4]. A civilization that can rely on renewable energy will be able to shift away from its reliance on fossil fuels towards the effective integration of renewable energy sources, including hydropower, wind, and solar, with EES systems, especially batteries [5]. Worldwide interest has been drawn in rechargeable lithium batteries owing to their potential as sustainable energy storage systems. These include solid state lithium batteries with solid state electrolyte, lithium oxygen (Li-O2) batteries, lithium sulfur (Li-S) batteries with sulfur composite cathode, emerging lithium metal batteries (LMBs) with intercalation-type cathode, and standard lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) [6,7]. Since their inception in 1991, lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries are regarded as one of the most intriguing EES technologies among the numerous types of rechargeable batteries. To store energy in Li-ion batteries, lithium ions are intercalated and deintercalated between an electrolyte-separated cathode and anode electrodes (Fig. 1 ). During charging, Li-ions move across the electrolyte from the cathode to the anode, storing energy in the Li-ion battery. They return to the cathode to give away energy in the discharging of the battery. An electrolyte, which generally comprises volatile and combustible solvents, facilitates the mobility of lithium ions. Because of the thermal instability, the potential for leakage, internal short circuits, and the flammability of electrolytes make safety a major concern in Li-ion batteries [1,8]. Therefore, electrolytes are important for EES devices to function at wider operating temperatures and greater potential windows [1]. Electrolytes have a significant impact on how well batteries operate in devices. A device's energy density, high ionic conductivity, low electrolyte resistance, low viscosity, etc., can all be improved by a broad potential window. Additionally, the power density of a device can also be improved by broad potential window of electrolyte [9,10]. Selecting appropriate electrolytes for EES systems is a significant task for researchers and industry players. Electrolytes are usually categorized into three types: solid, polymer, and liquid. Because of their strong intrinsic oxidation stabilities and somewhat appropriate electrochemical stabilities, solid electrolytes (SEs) are an appealing substitute for EES devices, nevertheless, their brittle nature prohibits their usage in EES device [9,10]. Polymer electrolytes (PEs) adaptability and versatility draw a lot of attention in a variety of EES devices. In LIBs, polymer electrolytes mainly consist of polyethylene oxide (PEO) and Li-salts. Nevertheless, the limited practical uses of PEs are due to their poor ionic conductivity at moderate temperatures [11,12]. In contrast, conventional liquid electrolytes show high ionic conductivity and great electrode compatibility, however, they provide safety issues for EES devices due to their flammability, fire danger, and catastrophic explosion [13,14]. When it comes to EES devices, there are typically three different kinds of liquid electrolytes consisting of ionic, organic, and aqueous electrolytes. Aqueous electrolytes (KOH, HCl, NaCl, KCl, H2SO4, etc.) offer greater concentration of ions and conductivity, but because of the water decomposition potential (1.2 V), they are only able to operate within a smaller potential window. Thus, the electrochemical stability and the energy density of the system are significantly decreased. The majority of solvent-based organic electrolytes, such as acetonitrile (ACN), propylene carbonate (PC) etc., have a significant potential of the order 3.5 V but there are concerns about safety, toxicity and high cost of organic electrolytes (Fig. 3). These disadvantages have been lessened in recent decades by ILs, which are non-toxic, have low volatility, high thermal stability (≥60 °C), non-flammability, good electrochemical stability (up to 6.0 V), and extended cycle stability (Figs. 2 and 3) [1,15,16]. The benefit of using ILs instead of organic electrolytes is that they enhance ion mobility and do away with the risks that come with using organic electrolytes. Furthermore, because of their remarkable thermal stability, ILs frequently have nearly zero or very little vapor pressure at room temperature. The aforementioned claims have resulted in an extensive utilization of ILs as electrolytes or solvents in applications utilizing energy storage in recent years [17,18]. Ionic liquids (ILs) have started to gain attention as substitute electrolyte over the past 20 years because of their capacity to link high-voltage cathode/anode pairs and their broad electro-chemical stability window [20]. However, low solubility of non-organic salts, and high viscosity of ordinary ILs at operational temperatures can all have a detrimental effect on energy performance [21]. Furthermore, these ILs may be costly and damaging to existing current collectors. Because of this, scientists are looking on safer, more environmentally friendly electrolytes having high ionic conductivity and chemical compatibility with the electrode materials of the cell [22]. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) have garnered significant interest as IL counterparts in recent years due to their shared favorable attributes with ILs, including non-flammability, low vapour pressure, high polarity, strong thermal and chemical stability, and the possibility of being tunable solvents (Figs. 2 and 3) [23]. Despite the characteristics similarity to ILs, DESs are expected to function better than conventional ILs. They have a 100% atom economy and are simple to manufacture in high purity without the need for any purification steps [24,25]. Notably, DESs can be helpful for wide-scale applications because of their low-cost and the abundance of bulk chemicals used as precursors [24]. DESs were suggested as alternative electrolytes for energy storage devices due to all these features, nevertheless, the area of DESs in electrochemistry is relatively young, it is growing very quickly [22]. Additionally, the salts utilized in the electrolyte play a significant role in ensuring the ionic conductivity and stability window of the electrolyte, making them an essential component. The most common commercial Li salt utilized in energy storage systems is lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6). LiPF6 displays greater ionic conductivities, corrosion protection for the Al current collector, and excellent electrochemical stability when dissolved in dipolar aprotic organic solvents such as linear carbonates like dimethyl, diethyl, and ethyl-methyl carbonate or cyclic carbonates like ethylene carbonate [26]. Due to its low heat stability and high susceptibility to moisture, LiPF6 remains an inferior lithium salt. This leads to the production of unwanted, highly reactive compounds like POF3 and HF, which cause the dissolution of transition metals from cathode material, reductively and oxidatively breakdown of solvents, and the degradation of interfacial protective layers on both electrodes [6]. Alternative salts with a better thermal stability that can rival LiPF6 in terms of the aforementioned performance-related attributes are needed in order to provide stability at higher temperatures [27]. This review provides a comprehensive overview of lithium salts, ILs, and DESs, emphasizing their significance and properties in electrochemical applications. It further examines various lithium salts used in electrolyte solutions for rechargeable lithium batteries, ranging from first-generation lithium salts like LiClO4 (lithium perchlorate), LiAsF6 (lithium hexafluoroarsenate), and LiBF4 (lithium tetrafluoroborate) to modern alternatives such as LiTFSI (lithium bis(trifluoromethyl sulfonyl)imide), LiFSI (Lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide), and LiBETI (Lithium bis(perfluoroethyl sulfonyl)imide). A concise discussion is also made on physicochemical and functional properties of ILs and DESs including electrochemical stability, ionic conductivity, viscosity, and nonflammability, with a focus on their influence on electrochemical performance. The review further explores the integration of lithium salts with ILs and DESs in advanced lithium battery technologies, such as Li-ion batteries, Li-O2 batteries, and Li-S batteries. It evaluates electrochemical performance metrics, including cycling stability, charge/discharge profiles, retention capacity and battery's coulombic efficiency based on reported systems. By summarizing recent advancements and challenges, this review highlights the potential of IL and DES based electrolytes in next-generation energy storage systems. Ultimately, this review aims to explore future research directions of ILs and DESs based electrolytic systems paving the way for more efficient and sustainable energy storage solutions. 2 Overview of the electrolytes consisting of Li salts, DESs, and ILs for energy storage applications 2.1 Li salts For the salts to be utilized in lithium-ion battery electrolytes, they must fulfill the following requirements: (1) Excellent chemical and heat stability. (2) It ought to be capable of protecting an aluminum (Al) current collector from anodic breakdown via passivation. (3) In a range of nonaqueous solvent systems, it ought to demonstrate high ionic conductivity. (4) At the cathode, the anion must be resistant to oxidative degradation. (5) For long-term cyclability and cell safety, it needs to be capable of creating solid-electrolyte interfaces (SEI) on electrodes that are less resistive, particularly on carbonaceous anodes. (6) It ought to be capable of fully dissolving and dissociating in non-aqueous systems. Additionally, solvated ions, particularly lithium cations, should have high mobility in the media. (7) Neither the cation nor the anion should react with the separator, electrode materials, or any other part of the cell. (8) Electrolyte solvents should not react with the anion. (9) The anion must not be harmful and must be strong enough to withstand heat-induced interactions with electrolyte solvents and other cell components [19]. Early research on metal-anode lithium batteries, conducted between 1970 and 1980, focused on Li-salts with a limited range of anions, such as trifluoromethanesulfonate (Tf) (CF3SO3), hexafluorophosphate (PF6 −), perchlorate (ClO4 −), and hexafluoroarsenate (AsF6 −) as shown in Table ST1 [5,19]. Electrolytes containing inexpensive and readily available LiClO4 offer high solubility, high ionic conductivity, and high anodic stability (in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate, up to 5.1 V on a spinel cathode surface), enabling effective passivation of aluminum and SEI formation on the negative electrode. Due to its affordable price, ease of handling, and increased stability over fluoro-type salts, it is one of the finest options being utilized in many laboratories for evaluating electrolytes. Nevertheless, because of chlorine's high oxidation state (VII), perchlorate is a potent oxidant that may react quickly with organic materials at higher temperatures and result in significant current charging and for this reason, it may be explosive. Because of its explosive properties, this salt cannot be utilized in practical batteries [19,29]. Numerous laboratories have studied LiAsF6 salt for usage in lithium battery electrolytes. In ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (1:1), it shows slightly better ionic conductivity (11.1 mS cm−1) than LiPF6 (10.7 mS cm−1) [19]. LiAsF6 has been found to be a better salt than LiClO4. It can dissolve in solvents with low dielectric constants, such as dimethyl carbonate and ethyl carbonate, and achieves an average cycling efficiency of over 95% [19]. Nevertheless, the high toxicity of arsenic and its compounds restricts the widespread use of lithium hexafluoroarsenate [29,30]. When graphite is used as the anode in γ-butyrolactone (GBL)-ethylene carbonate (EC) mixtures, LiBF4 is the only salt found to enable full charge-discharge cycles. At a temperature of 60 °C, C-LiFePO4/C-Li4Ti5O12 cells demonstrated acceptable electrochemical characteristics when 1.5 mol L−1 LiBF4 was added to GBL-EC (1:1) electrolyte when LiPF6 should be omitted due to its low thermal stability. In high-temperature Li-ion batteries, LiBF4 outperforms LiPF6 in EC:GBL electrolytes, regardless of whether LiFePO4 or LiCoO2 is utilized as the cathode [26,31]. Yet, anion BF4 − is poorly conducting and causes issues on Li surface [26,32]. Thermal and hydrolytic stability are demonstrated by lithium triflate (LiCF3SO3) [29]. As with LiPF6 and LiBF4, the sulfonate group (SO3Li)) in Li-(CF3SO3) exhibits non-toxicity, high oxidation resistance, and insensitivity to ambient moisture settings and also exhibits great thermal stability [19]. But in carbonate mixtures, its solutions show relatively poor conductivity and are unable to prevent Al from corroding (varying sources state that this process starts at 2.8, 3.3, or 3.8 V) [29]. Additionally, on the negative electrode, LiCF3SO3 generates the SEI with subpar characteristics [5,29,30]. The advancement of LIBs revealed that LiClO4 and LiAsF6 were unsuitable for use in commercial cells because of toxicity and safety issues. In a similar manner, the decline in the popularity of LiCF3SO3 salt is due to the comparatively poor conductivities of LiCF3SO3-salt contained electrolytes [5]. Significant effort has been devoted over the past few decades to innovate, synthesize, and analyze new lithium salts as potential substitute for LiPF6 [6,33,34]. The lithium imides typically lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI), lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (LiFSI)) and thermally and chemically stable lithium borates typically lithium bis(oxalato)borate (LiBOB), lithium difluoro(oxalato)borate (LiDFOB)) are some new alternative lithium salts which are studied for lithium batteries (Table S1) [6]. LiTFSI salt was demonstrated to be a viable lithium battery substitute during the commercialization phase, and soon after, a number of studies were published [35]. LiTFSI has a melting point of 236 °C and a breakdown temperature of 360 °C. Additionally, it is strongly conducting, for instance, LiTFSI solutions in mixed carbonates have conductivities that are comparable to LiPF6 solutions (Fig. 4 a) [29]. Also, it exhibits good dissociation in solvents with low dielectric constants, resulting in increased dissociation; also, the solution viscosity rises (mobility decreases), promoting better ionic conductivity because of the bigger size of anion. The oxidation potential of LiTFSI in ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate (1:1) binary solutions was determined 4.3 V vs. Li/Li+, which is much higher than that of other salts examined, aside from LiAsF6. The significant corrosion of Al current collector has prevented LiTFSI from being employed in commercially available rechargeable lithium-ion cells [19]. The salt LiFSI has high solubility and dissolves in dialkyl and alkylene carbonates as well as their mixtures, just like its parent, LiTFSI [29]. At −50 °C, LiFSI electrolytes in DMC/EMC (3:7) show remarkable conductivity of 0.9 × 10–4 S cm−1 [36]. Also, at room temperature, the conductivity of LiFSI in a mixed solvent (EC/EMC) is comparable to that of LiPF6 solutions (Fig. 4a) [29]. LiFSI is more hydrolysis-resistant and thermally stable than LiPF6 (decomposition starts at >180–200 °C for LiFSI) [29,37]. Given the constraints imposed by the corrosion of Al current collector, LiFSI-based electrolytes are not utilized commercially [38]. LiBETI (Li[N(C2F5SO2)2]) exhibits broader electrochemical stability window (ESW) (greater than 5.5 V vs. Li/Li+), and it has greater thermal stability and good cycling behavior than LiTFSI. Below room temperature, the conductivity of LiBETI solutions in a mixed solvent (EC/EMC) exceed the conductivity of LiPF6 in the same solution (Fig. 4b) [29]. It performs similarly to electrolytes based on LiPF6. Its high anodic current also significantly passivates the Al current collector and permits the formation of stable passivation layers on the surfaces of both the electrodes (the introduction of perfluoroethyl groups instead of trifluoromethyl groups in the LiTFSI salt has improved this property). Because of the nitrile group, LiBETI cannot be utilized in commercialized lithium-ion batteries. Users need to take extra caution when employing in lithium polymer batteries because of the C–F bond's instability and their thermodynamic instability in comparison to lithium metal [19,39,40]. Compared to LiPF6, tris(perfluoroethyl)trifluorophosphate (LiFAP) exhibits noticeably less reactivity toward carbonaceous anode materials. It possesses high anodic current and a wide electrochemical window of around 5.0 V versus Li/Li+. It can withstand temperatures as high as 220 °C. At room temperature, LiFAP and LiPF6 exhibit conductivities of around 8.2 and 10.7 mS cm−1 in ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate (50:50), respectively (Fig. 5 a) [29]. At 30 °C, LiFAP demonstrated a much lower irreversible capacity loss (19%) in comparison to electrolytes based on LiPF6 (49%). However, in a battery fire, this salt creates a lot of HF and is also very costly. The LiFAP/LiPF6 binary salt system is thought to have potential uses in rechargeable batteries that can withstand temperatures as high as 80 °C. This is especially advantageous for usage in electric vehicle applications [19]. The inclusion of fluorine (F) atoms in the structures of all of the aforementioned anions except ClO4 − and BOB− raises additional safety issues. BOB− and more modern F-free anions like dicyanotriazolate (DCTA or occasionally TADC) and tetracyanoborate (Bison) are intriguing options for LIBs in this regard [5]. The unique characteristics of lithium bis(oxalato)borate, or LiBOB, have garnered a lot of interest. The development of the SEI on cathodes and carbonaceous anodes has been demonstrated to be significantly influenced by BOB− anions. Al surface may be passivated by the BOB− anion just as effectively as by PF6 − and BF4 −. LiBOB shows a conductivity of 10–2–10–3 S cm−1 at temperatures above 0 °C (Fig. 5b) [29]. However, LiBOB's solubility in most aprotic solvents is restricted [5,6]. Both Bison and DCTA have good thermal stabilities, but their Li-salt electrolytes have poor ionic conductivities and relatively low oxidation potentials. Some have tried to add F-species to these salts in an attempt to enhance their qualities, but doing so comes with higher manufacturing costs and safety issues. To adjust the characteristics of the BOB− anion, numerous anions based on borate were created, such as bis(fluoromalonato)-borate (BFMB) [5]. Analogously, it has been demonstrated that various imidazole or benzimidazole based anions, as well as dicyano-trifluoromethyl-imidazole (TDI) and dicyano-pentafluoroethyl-imidazole (PDI), are more promising than DCTA [5,6,41]. Recent advancements in lithium salts such as LiTFSI, LiFSI, and LiBOB have demonstrated to improve stability and conductivity, yet challenges such as corrosion, low solubility, limited compatibility, and safety risks still exist. To address these challenges, future efforts should focus on optimizing molecular designs for safer and more efficient salts, exploring hybrid salt systems for synergistic benefits, developing fluorine-free alternatives to enhance safety and reduce costs, incorporating additives and novel solvents to improve stability and performance, and adopting scalable, cost-effective synthesis methods for commercial viability. These approaches can drive the development of safer and high-performance electrolytes for next-generation lithium-ion batteries. 2.2 ILs Low-temperature molten salts made up of ions with melting temperatures below 100 °C are known as ILs [42,43]. These systems have been fascinating topics for study and inquiry ever since the first ionic liquid was discovered in 1914, [N(C2H5)H3][NO3] [44]. In the past few years, ILs have grown more popular and are in high demand due to their remarkable properties, which include superior safety over organic solvent electrolytes, a wide electrochemical stability window, great thermal stability, and impressive ionic conductivity (varying from 1 to 10 mS cm−1) at room temperature. They have been the focus of much research and have found several uses due to these special qualities [42]. Organic and inorganic anions and organic cations with a significant molecular weight and volume make up ionic liquids. The physicochemical properties of ILs are the result of the van der Waals, hydrogen bonding, and coulombic interactions between the cations and anions. Therefore, the production of a broad variety of functionalized ILs is made possible by the capacity to modify the ions along with the cation–anion combinations [45]. Because of the weaker coulombic attraction and lower lattice energy between organic cations and anions that interact with one another, ionic liquids have far lower melting temperatures than ionic crystals [42,46]. Ionic liquids have a number of special qualities, including low vapor pressure, low-volatility, high ionic conductivity, non-toxic properties, non-flammability, and great thermodynamic stability [43,47]. Imidazolium, pyrrolidinium, piperidinium, quaternary ammonium/phosphonium, and sulfonium compounds are the most often utilized cations in ILs [42]. By adding different functional groups to the ring's or branch chain's carbon atoms, all of the ILs' cations may be altered, for instance, adding nitrile to the alkyl of the cation 1-alkyl-3-methylimidazolium [48]. The substituent placement in a chain as well as its length and the size of the cation, all affect the ILs' thermal stability, ionic conductivity, viscosity, and electrochemical properties [47]. Additionally, anions of ILs, including [N(CN)2]−, [Ag(CN)2]−, [C (CN)3]−, and so on, are often based on cyano groups [49]. Furthermore, several other anions, including halides (Cl−, Br−), tetrafluoroborates ([BF4]−), hexafluorophosphates ([PF6]−), trifluoroacetic ([CF3CO2]−), triflates ([CF3SO3]−), and bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide ([N(CF3SO2)2]−) might interact with different cations to produce particular properties. Depending on the various cation and anion configurations and combinations, countless different species could theoretically exist [50,51]. Fig. 6 depicts the usual cations and anions present in ionic liquids. The ionic liquids containing BF4 − and PF6 − anions react aggressively with Lewis acid but are generally stable in air and water. Ionic liquids with TFSI− and FSI− anions, on the other hand, are more stable. The following benefits make [TFSI]− and [FSI]− the most often utilized anions among others. First, the ionic liquid's fluidity is enhanced by the highly delocalized charge distribution, which successfully lessens anion-cation interaction. Second, the system is very flexible and has a low melting point and viscosity because the SO2CF3 groups at both ends of the anion may be rotated to create alternative configurations. Finally, the safety of electrolytes can be enhanced by their strong thermal, chemical, and electrochemical stability [52]. By using various cation-anion combinations, a large variety of task-specific ILs have been produced so far for different applications including the creation of IL composites, gas separation, biomedicine, electrocatalysis/photocatalysis and biomass pretreatment. ILs are widely used as electrolyte elements in energy storage and conversion systems because of the aforementioned characteristics, which include greater electrochemical stability, increased safety, and the tendency to develop interfaces. IL electrolytes can significantly influence battery performance by preventing electrode dissolution and diffusion in the electrolyte [42]. Thus, using ILs as electrolyte components is quite advantageous for EES devices [47]. 2.2.1 Properties of ILs 2.2.1.1 Melting point An essential physical property of ionic liquids is their melting point but relationship between ionic liquids' structure and melting point is still unclear. A lower melting point is generally found in ionic liquids with a higher cation volume, longer alkyl side chains, poorer symmetry and greater distribution of cation charge [52–54]. However, raising the side chain to a particular level won't affect the melting point. Therefore, 6–8 C atoms are the optimal number for the side chain. A high melting point is produced by a cationic structure with a high branched alkyl chain. For instance, the melting point of [iPrMeIm]+ with an isopropyl group is greater than that of [PrMeIm]+ with an n-propyl group. Furthermore, substituting an alkyl group for the proton at the imidazole ring's 2-position C raises the melting point of imidazole-based ionic liquids [55]. The strong electron-withdrawing group in anions like [N(CF3SO2)2]− makes the negative charge more diffuse, reducing the cation-anion interaction and thereby lowering the melting point [52]. 2.2.1.2 Thermal stability When it comes to thermal stability, the majority of ionic liquids are superior to organic electrolyte solvents. At 100 °C, carbonate-based liquid electrolyte solvents often volatilize. Ionic liquids, on the other hand, have a pyrolysis temperature exceeding 300 °C and a nearly zero vapor pressure, making them non-flammable and non-explosive [56]. One benefit of using ILs as lithium-ion battery electrolytes is that they can lessen safety issues brought on by the electrolytes' volatilization while the battery is operating. ILs thermal stability is contingent upon the chemical structure and characteristics of their anions and cations [57]. Ionic liquids based on imidazole offer better thermal stability for cations compared to quaternary ammonium and pyridine-based ionic liquids. Additionally, alkyl groups aid in improving heat stability by replacing protons on the imidazole's 2-position C atom. A number of common anions have the following order of thermal stability: PF6 − > N(C2F5SO2)2 − > N(CF3SO2)2 − ≈ BF4 − > C(CF3SO2)3 − ≫ Cl−, Br−, and I− [52,58,59]. 2.2.1.3 Viscosity and ionic conductivity The electrolyte's viscosity and ionic conductivity have a significant impact on energy storage devices' performance. Conductivity and viscosity are strongly related in liquid electrolytes [42]. Ion mobility and the quantity of charge carriers determine an ionic liquid's conductivity. There are enough charge carriers because the ionic liquid is entirely made up of anions and cations, nevertheless, due to the unavoidable ion associations, the number of carriers will diminish, which will lower the conductivity [55]. Viscosity, which has an inverse relationship with conductivity across a broad range of temperatures, is another crucial factor influencing the conductivity of ionic liquids [60]. The ionic conductivity and viscosity data of some representative ILs are listed in Table ST2. At 25 °C, the viscosity of water is 0.89 cP. ILs, in contrast have a substantially greater viscosity, between 30 and 50 cP and occasionally as much as 500–600 cP [61]. Although IL has demonstrated encouraging results as a liquid electrolyte, there is currently little industrial use of it. This is mostly because of criteria like high viscosity, high cost, and the demand for pure ingredients [42,62]. At room temperature, however, it has been noted that IL-based electrolytes function worse than traditional electrolytes. The main causes of this include ILs' high viscosity and resistance to ionic transfer. However, they perform better at temperatures between 40 and 50°C [42,63]. The electrolyte including lithium salt, LiTFSI and IL (N-propyl-N-methylpyrrolidinium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide) (Pyr13TFSI) has a reduced ionic conductivity of 1.5 × 10−3 S cm−1 and a greater viscosity of 180 cP. In contrast, at 30 °C, the hybrid electrolytes has an ionic conductivity of 3 × 10−3 S cm−1 and viscosity of 110 mPa s [42,64]. Ethylene carbonate (EC) is an organic solvent utilized in commercial organic liquid electrolytes, with a viscosity of 1.9 cP at 25 °C. In comparison, ILs typically exhibit much higher viscosities than traditional organic solvents [42,61]. The substantial size of organic cations and their restricted structural flexibility are responsible for the higher viscosities of several IL-based electrolytes. This increased viscosity may lead to comparatively reduced ionic mobility as well as insufficient wetness across the electrode and electrolyte [42]. The conductivity of pure ionic liquids, such as Pyr13TFSI, is around 5 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C, and viscosity is normally about 60 mPa s [65]. But when 2 wt% LiTFSI is added, the conductivity drops to 8 × 10−4 S cm−1 and the viscosity raises to 250 mPa s [64]. Therefore, using low-viscosity ILs can help in increasing the ionic conductivity of electrolytes based on ILs. LIB electrolytes frequently use IL compositions made up of cations like 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazole ([EtMeIm]+)/1-butyl-3-methylimidazole ([BuMeIm]+) and anions like TFSI−/BF4 − or N-methyl-N-propylpyrrolidinium ([PrMePy]+)/N-methyl-N-butylpyrrolidinium ([BuMePy]+)/N-methylN-hexylpyrrolidinium ([HexMePy]+) cation coupled with dicyanamides ([N(CN)2]−) anion. Often used in LiB electrolytes, these IL compositions have low viscosities between 20 and 50 cP [42]. 2.2.1.4 Electrochemical stability For ionic liquids to be employed in lithium batteries, the electrochemical window is crucial. ILs, the electrolytes of lithium metal batteries, must preserve a specific level of electrochemical stability throughout the operations of charging and discharging. In ionic liquids, the cations usually measure the reduction potential and the anions measure the oxidation potential. Though, the cation determines both the ionic liquid's oxidation potential and reduction potential when its oxidation stability is lower than the anion. The anion determines both the oxidation and the reduction potentials of the ionic liquid when its reduction stability is lower than the cation [52]. Electrochemical stability based on chain quaternary ammonium IL is superior to those based on imidazolium-based IL. The potential for oxidation exceeds 5.0 V vs. Li+/Li, whereas the potential for reduction falls below 0 V vs. Li+/Li [55]. In comparison to the most commonly used ionic liquids based on imidazolium (1.4–4.5 V vs. Li+/Li), piperidinium-based ionic liquids exhibit a significantly wider electrochemical window [66]. Mono cationic ILs with a particular anion have been the subject of study on the usage of ILs in lithium-ion batteries. Nevertheless, despite the benefits they provide in this situation, dicationic ILs are still seldom used in LIBs. Specially made for LIBs, asymmetrical imidazolium-trialkylammonium ILs have an electrochemical stability window (>5 V vs. Li/Li+) that is equivalent to the ILs based on quaternary ammonium. Moreover, like imidazolium-based ILs, they exhibit comparatively enhanced conductivity (>5 × 10−4 S cm−1) [67]. These dicationic ILs can be used to overcome the drawbacks of imidazolium-based ILs, which have limited electrochemical windows, and quaternary ammonium-based ILs, which have low ionic conductivity. ILs offer high thermal stability, wide electrochemical windows, and low volatility, making them suitable for energy storage. However, their high viscosity limits ion mobility, and challenges such as high costs, complex synthesis, and low-temperature performance hinder adoption. To address these challenges, future research should focus on developing low-viscosity, task-specific ILs with improved ionic conductivity, cost-effective synthesis, and expanded electrochemical windows. Additionally, IL integration into solid-state systems and the development of sustainable, non-toxic ILs will enhance commercial viability. 2.3 DESs In the last two decades, DESs have gained more attention as a new class of green solvents comparable to ILs after a study by Abbott et al. found an unusually deep melting point depression at the eutectic composition of certain HBDs (hydrogen bond donors) and HBAs (hydrogen bond acceptors) [68,69]. DESs are primarily composed of two molecules: one that provides a hydrogen bond (HBD) and the other that receives a hydrogen bond (HBA). These molecules have the potential to self-assemble into a new eutectic phase, which is lower than the melting temperatures of its constituent parts (below room temperature) [70,71]. In contrast to traditional ILs, which rely primarily on electrostatic interactions between anions and cations, DESs are complex assemblies generated by the mixing of molecular and ionic species. The liquid state of DES is dependent on a more intricate network of structures, which includes contributions from electrostatic or van der Waals forces in addition to dominating hydrogen bonds [24,25]. Several properties of DESs and ILs are similar, including nonflammability, low vapor pressure (usually less than 100 Pa at 373 K), compositional tunability and good thermal and chemical stability. These characteristics make DESs appealing substitutes for the approximately 600 volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and are now widely utilized in industry and research [28,68]. DESs also exhibit comparatively high surface tensions and viscosities [24]. However, DESs have additional advantages over typical ILs, such as being easier to manufacture, less expensive, and not water-sensitive. Furthermore, preliminary research revealed that DESs decompose naturally [22,24,68]. Due to the aforementioned features, DESs have the potential to be functioning electrolytes and innovative nanomaterial precursors for electrochemical energy storage and conversion (EESC) systems that are ecologically beneficial [28]. The discovery of DESs was a major breakthrough, and their low cost and versatile physicochemical properties have helped several industries. DESs have been used in much more diverse electrochemical processes, such as gas adsorption, metal electrodeposition, metal compounds extracted and treated from metal oxides, metal electropolishing, alloy coatings, synthesis and catalysis, solvents for synthesizing metal nanoparticle electrodes, composite coatings, and numerous others, in addition to electrolytes in energy storage applications [22,24]. Abbott provided a standard formula (Cat+X− zY) for the classification of DESs based on the kind of HBD and HBA utilized for DES formation. Cat+ in the formula is mainly an ammonium cation, and it can also be a sulfonium or phosphonium cation. The complex anionic species in the formula is formed by the combination of X (a halide anion that serves as a Lewis base) and Y (a Lewis acid or Brønsted base). The symbol z represents the number of Y molecules interacting with the anion (Fig. 7 ) [22]. DESs may be broadly divided into five groups using various classification schemes. Type I DESs combine a metal chloride and a quaternary ammonium salt (Cat+ X− + zMCl x ), such as ChCl + ZnCl2. A quaternary ammonium salt and a metal chloride hydrate (Cat+X− + zMCl x ·yH2O), such as ChCl + CoCl2·6H2O, make up type II DESs [22,72]. Hydrated metal salts are well-known for being inexpensive, air and moisture resistant, and appropriate for use in industrial settings. A quaternary ammonium salt and an HBD (Cat+X− + zRZ), such as ChCl + urea, make up type III DESs. Finally, a metal chloride and an HBD (zMCl x + zRZ), as ZnCl2 + urea, combine to generate Type IV DESs [22,72]. The newly identified class Type V is made up only of nonionic, molecular HBDs and HBAs [73,74]. Type II DESs can be made by mixing hydrated metal halides with ChCl, but Type I DESs are hard to make due to the scarcity of non-hydrated metal halides with the required low melting temperatures. Because of their natural resistance to oxygen and moisture, many hydrated metal salts are affordable and can be employed in enormous industrial activities. The power of Type III DESs for dissolving a number of transition metal compounds, including chlorides and oxides, make them interesting. These substances are composed of HBDs and ChCl as HBAs [70,75]. Previous studies have shown that eutectics have melting temperatures lower as 150 °C may be produced from metal halide and urea compositions. Moreover, eutectics may include a range of transition metals, now known as Type IV DESs, at standard temperature settings [76]. In non-aqueous solutions, these metal complexes seldom decompose into ions, although ZnCl2 has been shown to do so when mixed with ethylene glycol, urea, and acetamide [22]. Type V DESs are believed to have a higher prevalence of hydrogen bonding since they are missing an ionic component despite have DES melting point features [77]. Additionally, Natural DES (NADES) is another novel type of DESs which have lately drawn increased interest because these are created by adding natural ingredients [22]. The physicochemical characteristics of eutectic systems, such as ionic conductivity, surface tension, viscosity, and melting point, are directly linked to intermolecular interactions. For the formation of eutectic electrolytes, the intermolecular interactions between several components must be greater than the original intermolecular interactions within each component [78,79]. As seen in Fig. 8 , eutectic electrolyte production is often dominated by three types of interactions and hydrogen-bond interactions make up the first category. This powerful impact is the foundation for the majority of DES-type eutectic electrolytes. This kind of eutectic combination has one HBD, including alcohol, amide, and carboxylic acid molecules, and at least one HBA, like metal halides, choline chloride (ChCl), and other quaternary ammonium salt analogs (Fig. 8). One HBA and the hydrogen-donor moiety form a comparatively strong hydrogen bond, which reduces their individual intermolecular interactions and lowers the mixture's melting point. The capacity of each component to establish hydrogen bonds with each another determines the ideal molar ratio of HBD to HBA. An eutectic electrolyte, ChCl, and urea, for example, has a eutectic point at 1:2 M ratio, but a combination of ChCl and thiourea has a eutectic point at 1:3 [22,78]. Consequently, by employing distinct HBDs, the physicochemical characteristics of eutectic electrolytes may be modified. Despite having comparable molecular size of urea and acetamide, the respective eutectic electrolytes with ZnCl2 have significantly different viscosity. This results from urea's two NH2 functions, which form stronger hydrogen bonds than acetamide's single NH2 functionality [78]. The hydrogen-bonding network has the most influence on the melting point, as per the findings of a topological and DFT investigation of the electronic density for DESs [22]. The interaction mechanism and chemical structure of glycol-based DESs were predicted by COSMO-RS in a distinct investigation. The conclusion was that some more hydrogen bond interactions could have taken place in the course of DESs’ synthesis, along with the previously identified hydrogen bond interactions [80,81]. Lewis acid-base interactions are the second category of interactions, which follows Lewis theory of acids and bases. Lewis bases have the ability to give electron pairs, whereas Lewis acids have the ability to receive them [82]. All cations, as well as some chemical compounds including BF3 and PF3 are Lewis acids whereas anions and compounds like C6H5CH2NH2, NH3, and PH3 are the Lewis bases [78]. The hydrogen bond interaction discussed above might be considered a subclass of the Lewis acid-base interactions. Yet, it must be discussed individually because of the crucial function that this hydrogen bond interaction plays between hydrogen atoms and more electronegative atoms. Depending on the identity of the Lewis acid and base donors, the intensity of Lewis acid-base interactions can vary significantly. It can be as strong as certain covalent bonds (>100 kJ mol−1) or as weak as a hydrogen bond (4 kJ mol−1) [83]. Indeed, a Lewis chemical reaction (covalent bonding) was not anticipated to be facilitated by the Lewis acid-base interaction in eutectic electrolytes. Only altering the coordination environment would be ideal, generating a eutectic electrolyte having low melting point. Usually Lewis acids, Li+, Na+, and K+ alkali cations can theoretically produce eutectic electrolytes with a range of molecules that have Lewis base moieties, including ether, carbonate, and amide (Fig. 8). Lithium batteries and supercapacitors have already been reported to use eutectic electrolytes based on different Li salts (LiTFSI, LiNO3, and LiPF6) and N-methylacetamide (NMAc), urea or acetamide molecules [84]. Of these, the TFSI− anion's greater degree of charge delocalization would be ideal for producing eutectic electrolytes with low viscosity and high ionic conductivity [78]. Vander Waals interactions comprise the third kind of interactions, which include London dispersion forces, Keesom forces (dipole-dipole effect), and Debye forces (dipole-induced dipole effect). Electrostatic processes constitute the basis for the first two of these effects. Fig. 8 depicts the Keesom force, which is caused by a permanent dipole in another permanent dipole, the Debye force, which is defined as the attraction energy between a polar molecule and a nonpolar molecule, and the London dispersion force, which is generated by induced dipoles caused by electronic polarizations in interacting atoms. Vander Waals interactions range in strength from 0.4 to 4 kJ mol−1, making them the weakest of all chemical forces. Vander Waals interactions, however, are crucial for the system as a whole since they can occur between any two molecules. Overall, van der Waals interactions dominate in the eutectic, occurring only when the original intermolecular forces within each component are weaker than the newly formed van der Waals forces [22,85,86]. Together with other interactions, Van der Waals forces really play a major role in adjusting the physicochemical characteristics of eutectic electrolytes. These three interactions collectively influence the formation of eutectic solvents. In order to screen these materials for usage in different energy storage applications, it would be helpful to provide further details about the eutectic electrolyte formation process. By changing the number of functions, substituents, and mixture composition, it is possible to adjust the intermolecular interactions and enhance the phase behavior and characteristics of eutectic electrolytes. Since DESs are primarily concerned with their properties, a detailed examination of the physicochemical and electrochemical characteristics of these liquids is required for the effective DES design and the rational exploration of their possible applications [22,78]. 2.3.1 Properties of DESs Due to emerging physicochemical and electrochemical characteristics of DESs, researchers are showing intense interest in them. The potential use of DESs as solvents in the energy and industrial sectors has been explored. They are also known as “designer solvents” since any combination of HBA and HBD may be customized to produce a variety of DESs. A large range of HBA and HBD mixes with unique molar ratio may be used to change the physicochemical characteristics of DESs. Temperature, water content, HBA and HBD purity, and method of preparation are the variables that affect the physicochemical and electrochemical characteristics of DESs along with the existing HBA to HBD ratio [22,68]. The physicochemical and electrochemical characteristics of DESs associated with EESC applications, such as solubility, ionic conductivity, vapor pressure, nonflammability, viscosity, and electrochemical stability window (ESW) are discussed here. Some DES-based electrolytes are charted in Table ST3 representing viscosity and ionic conductivity data at working temperature. 2.3.1.1 Vapor pressure and nonflammability Vapor pressure represents the pressure exerted by the vapor phase of a substance when it is in thermodynamic equilibrium with its condensed forms. It is a crucial characteristic to take into account when choosing a solvent since it affects handling and storage as well as the solvent's volatility. DESs typically exhibit a relatively low vapor pressure as compared to conventional organic solvents, preventing air pollution and lowering associated concerns such as vapor flammability [87]. For example, at 313 K, Boisset et al. reported a vapor pressure 20 Pa for the LiTFSI and NMAc DES (1:4 M ratio), which is significantly lower than that of acetonitrile (1.02 × 105 Pa at 298 K) and water (7380 Pa at 313 K) [88]. This vapor pressure, however, is significantly greater than that found in aprotic ILs. Using an isothermal thermogravimetric technique, Ravula and colleagues showed that typical ChCl-based DESs, including reline, ethaline, and glyceline, have vapor pressure ranging from 2.12 to 161.95 Pa at 313.15 to 433.15 K. They also arranged the liquids according to decreasing vapor pressure: short-chain PEGs > long-chain PEGs > DESs > protic ILs > polymeric ILs > aprotic ILs > dicationic ILs [89]. Dietz et al. recently evaluated the vapor pressure of six hydrophobic DESs using headspace gas chromatography/mass spectrometry at 373 K. The findings indicated a range of vapor pressures, from 540.9 Pa for decanoic acid: menthol (1:1) to 55.5 Pa for decanoic acid: lidocaine (2:1) [90]. DESs are the perfect nonflammable solvent owing to their high thermal breakdown temperature and comparatively low vapor pressure. The inherently nonflammable DESs have garnered a lot of interest lately as safe electrolytes for EES devices, especially high-temperature batteries [28]. 2.3.1.2 Viscosity and ionic conductivity Since viscosity significantly affects mass transport in eutectic solvents, it is a crucial factor in deciding the viability of DESs for EESC applications. Intermolecular interactions in DES components are closely linked to viscosity. For instance, at a 1:4 M ratio, the viscosity of the LiTFSI and NMAc-based DES electrolyte is lower than that of its LiPF6/NMAc and LiNO3/NMAc counterparts, due to the larger size and higher charge delocalization of the TFSI− anion [84]. As a result of lowered viscosity of LiTFSI/NMAc-based DES electrolyte, lithium storage kinetics is enhanced. Additionally, a significant factor in determining viscosity is the hydrogen bond donor (HBD) species. Because of the greater hydrogen bonding that results from substituting acetamide (Ace) for NMAc, the viscosity of the resultant LiTFSI/Ace eutectic is over 100 mPa s (at 25 °C) greater than that of LiTFSI/NMAc (78.38 mPa s) [84,91]. Another important factor in determining the viscosity of DES is the water content in DES. The viscosity of DES made of ChCl:urea (1:2) decreased from 527.3 to 200.6 cP upon the addition of a 0.1-mole proportion of water. Temperature has a major impact on viscosity in addition to DES composition [92]. High temperatures can result in low viscosities, and vice versa, because DESs typically exhibit a negative connection between two parameters. Another important factor influencing the use of eutectic solvents in EESC is ionic conductivity. The ability of a material to permit the passage of ions or current through ionic conduction is measured by its ionic conductivity. As previously mentioned, the Vogel-Tamann-Fulher (VTF) equation shows that DES's ionic conductivity frequently increases when the temperature rises owing to a drop in viscosity [92]. Increasing the temperature from 25 to 80 °C, for instance, improves the ionic conductivity of Zn(TFSI)2/Ace [93]. Because of the enhanced ion transport kinetics, batteries and supercapacitors using DES as the electrolyte typically exhibit better performance at high temperatures. Furthermore, the species of salts or HBDs in addition to the salt and HBD molar ratio, determine the conductivity of organic salt/HBD DES (Table S3). For Zn(TFSI)2/Ace DES, ionic conductivity rises by almost three times when the HBD:Zn salt ratio is adjusted from 4:1 to 9:1 [93]. According to recent research, DESs made of ILs as HBAs have ionic conductivities of more than 5 mS cm−1, making them appropriate for use in a range of applications requiring high conductivity [94]. For electrolytes in electrochemical systems, DESs with a low viscosity are advantageous since rapid mass movement is desired. But other safety-related factors, such as thermal, chemical, and electrochemical stability, should also be taken very seriously [95–97]. 2.3.1.3 Electrochemical stability window (ESW) A solvent's range of potentials within which it remains stable and does not suffer chemical breakdown is known as the “Electrochemical Stability Window” (ESW). Because of their broad electrochemical stability window, DESs are appealing for usage in electrochemical processes like electrodeposition, electroplating, and electrosynthesis. Therefore, DESs' electrochemical activity at the electrode-DES interface is a critical characteristic in electrochemical applications [22]. In a study of ChCl-based DESs, researchers put forwarded that HBDs determine the negative limit of polarization or potential, above which the electrolyte can be oxidized. It increases in the following order for HBDs: 1,3-propanediol, urea, EG, and 1,2-propanediol. Additionally, the researchers discovered that raising the temperature of the DESs increased the observed capacitive current and decreased the electrochemical window (EW) [98,99]. In different research, the DES composed of ChCl and methyl urea had the greatest potential window among the investigated systems, ChCl, ChI, ChBr, and methyl urea-based DESs [100]. Electrochemical windows of 3–4 V have been developed for DESs that comprise alkali metal salts and glycerol (Gly), ethylene glycol (EG) or polyethylene glycol (PEG), satisfying the requirements for electrochromic devices (ECD) compatibility [101]. DESs based on EG and LiTFSI demonstrated a high electrochemical window of around 4.5 V against Li+/Li [102]. Another work provides two DESs based on sodium and lithium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imides with formamide and N-methylacetamide as electrolytes for use in activated carbon supercapacitors (ACS) at 25 °C. These DESs exhibit moderate viscosity (11.3 mPa s), a broad electrochemical window (>2.5 V) high thermal stability (up to about 150 °C), and ionic conductivity in the 3–4 mS cm−1 range [103]. 2.3.1.4 Solubility Metal salts and other ionic species exhibit great solubility in DESs owing to their ionic composition and comparatively high polarity. DESs are being utilized to create functional nanomaterials for EESC using chemical and electrochemical methods because of their exceptional solubility. Due to their affordable prices, low vapor pressures, and exceptional solubility of numerous metal precursors, ChCl-based DESs are particularly popular as solvents. In order to create electrode materials and electrocatalysts with unique morphologies and characteristics, a number of metal precursors, including NiCl2·6H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, CoCl2·6H2O, H2PtCl6·6H2O, and La(NO3)3, have demonstrated a remarkable solubility in DESs based on ChCl [28,104,105]. The formation of carbonaceous materials benefits from the fact that DESs dissolve organic molecules significantly more readily compared to water. Common metal oxides have lately been shown to dissolve in DESs in a number of papers, with some compositions even outperforming acids in this regard [106]. Consequently, DESs have garnered a lot of interest for recycling precious metals from used batteries. The elevated concentration of metal ions in the DESs is a notable indication that raising the temperature significantly improves the DESs' capacity for dissociation. Another practical strategy to improve the solubility of metal oxides is to lower the salt:HBD molar ratio [22,28]. DESs have shown remarkable potential in diverse applications due to their tunable properties, low cost, and eco-friendliness. However, several challenges hinder their broader adoption. Optimizing the viscosity-conductivity balance is still a major issue, as high viscosity restricts ion transport and reduces efficiency in electrochemical systems. Additionally, the complex nature of intermolecular interactions in DESs calls for advanced theoretical and experimental studies to design tailored solvents. Future research should focus on improving DESs' electrochemical stability, widening their stability window, enhancing their conductivity through innovative compositions, and exploring their interactions with water to develop water-in-DES systems for improved solubility and performance. These efforts will help harness the full potential of DESs in energy storage, catalysis, recycling, and beyond. 3 Application of ILs in lithium batteries 3.1 Lithium-ion batteries Traditionally, 1 M LiTFSI in ternary ether solvents or 1 M LiPF6 in binary carbonate solvents have been employed as the electrolyte when using LIBs. Because of the extreme volatility and flammability of these organic electrolytes, there can be a major safety risk [107]. Additionally, the persistent creation of an SEI layer may lead to lithium's dendritic development, which may short circuit LIBs. For the improved LIBs, it is therefore very important to have electrolytes with great thermal stability and minimal volatility. One of the best characteristics of ILs is their non-flammability, which addresses the primary safety concern of LIBs [108]. To improve the electrolyte's thermal stability, Zaghib et al. suggested the addition of [EMI][TFSI] to the electrolyte of LIBs [109]. According to Chen et al., the [PP13][TFSI] electrolyte and LiTFSI considerably increase low temperature performance and rate capacity while being safer than traditional electrolytes [110]. Furthermore, even at high temperatures, LIBs' excellent performance and cycle stability were enhanced by the use of inorganic alkali salts having comparatively lower melting points. For example, in the 40–150 °C range, Zhibin et al. observed that potassium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide ([KFSI]) and [LiFSI] dual-salt-mixture has significant ionic conductivity (about 10−3–10−2 S cm−1) [111]. Hirano et al. produced an oligo (ethylene oxide) substituent-functionalized organosilicon ammonium IL. Large cations were present in all ILs synthesized in this manner, and they all have shown excellent thermal stability displaying a stability window of 3.9–4.7 V (vs. Li/Li+) and higher decomposition temperatures (310–350 °C). At room temperature (RT), they also exhibited low viscosity (125–173 cP). However, because of their poor conductivity, they were unsuitable for LIB electrolytes. Consequently, to create a hybrid electrolyte, commercial carbonate electrolyte was combined with organosilicon functionalized ammonium ILs which have an oligo (ethylene oxide) substituent. The lithium iron phosphate (LFP) electrode/Li half-cell demonstrated high reversible capacity and cycle stability at a doping level of 30 vol%, therefore improving lithium storage performance by effectively suppressing electrolyte breakdown due to stable SEI formation [113,114]. Using LiFSI salt and [C3mpyr][FSI], Howlett et al. established a high energy density LIB system that inhibited dendritic development even at a rapid charging rate. With a 0.2 V polarization and functioning at high current densities, the coulombic efficiency climbed to 96% at 20 mA cm−2 [115]. X-ray photoelectron microscopy (XPS), time-of-flight secondary-ion mass spectroscopy (ToF-SIMS), and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) surface measurements revealed that the formation of a stable SEI, rich in LiF and deficient in organic carbon species, coupled with nondendritic and compact Li morphologies enabled enhanced cycling efficiency at higher currents. High concentrations of LiTFSI and [Py13][FSI] were combined to create an ionic liquid electrolyte by Chen et al., which proved to be electrochemically compatible with various cathode materials. At 60 °C, the high-voltage 4.4 V LiCoO2/Li battery with this heavily concentrated electrolyte demonstrated outstanding cycling stability and great coulombic efficiency, retaining 94.2% of its capacity after 60 cycles at 0.2 C (Fig. 9 a and b). This electrolyte based on ionic liquid had an electrochemical stability window of up to 5.4 V (vs. Li/Li+) [112]. In contrast to employing LiPF6/EC/DEC alone, Wu et al. found that adding [Py13][TFSI] to LiPF6/EC/DEC organic electrolyte encouraged the creation of a more compact and homogenous cathode/electrolyte interphase layer with a significantly smaller thickness of around 2 nm. This was attributed to a decrease in the electrolyte's oxidative breakdown and less dissolution of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 (LNMO), which was thought to be essential for the electrode's excellent cycling stability. After 300 cycles at 1 C, the LNMO/Li battery demonstrated outstanding cycling stability with 97% capacity retention within the increased voltage scale between 3.5 and 5.0 V [116]. A few publications have described dicationic ionic liquids, which consist of two singly charged anions and two cationic groups connected by either a rigid or flexible hydrocarbon [50,117]. In LIBs employing LiMn2O4 (LMO) as the cathodic active material, dicationic ILs based on LiTFSI doped asymmetrical imidazolium-trialkylammonium exhibit encouraging electrochemical results with a high reversible capacity (90 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C) and rapid rate capability (Fig. 9c) [67]. Nirmale et al. synthesized an Imidazolium-based dicationic ionic liquid, [C6(mim)2][TFSI]2, which exhibited a wide electrochemical stability window up to 5.3 V and high ionic conductivity of 1.02 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 30 °C (Table 1 ), increasing to 6.58 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 70 °C. Impedance study shows that deposition of stable SEI layer favors long-term cycling stability. A Li/LiFePO4 cell utilizing this electrolyte at a 0.1 C rate demonstrated a capacity of 133 mAh g−1 at the 100th cycle with 98.8% of coulombic efficiency [118]. Paillard et al. also examined the LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 (NCM 523)/graphite full cells' electrochemical performance. According to these investigations, [Pyr14][TFSI], [Pyr14][DCA], and [Pyr14][TFSAM] demonstrated better electrochemical behavior in (NCM 523)/graphite full cells in comparison to electrolytes based on organic carbonate solvents [119]. 3.2 Lithium-sulfur batteries Li-S batteries have gained attention as next-generation LIBs since 1960 because of their high specific energy of 2510 Wh kg−1 and high theoretical capacity of 1667 mAh g−1 [120,121]. Nevertheless, there are other significant issues like shuttle effect with these types of batteries. The lithium's dendritic development, the spontaneous production of the SEI layer, and the lengthy polysulfide chain dissolving in the electrolyte all contribute to the comparatively low coulombic efficiency (CE) and cycle stability [108,122]. Li-S batteries are therefore forced to rely on electrolytes. A lot of research has been done to enhance the electrochemical characteristics of Li-S batteries and eliminate their faults [108,123]. When Li-S batteries were exposed to ILs, their performance has been found considerably improved. When an IL was utilized as a Li-S battery electrolyte, Yang et al. discovered that, in comparison to organic electrolytes, the ILs significantly improved sulfur usage and electrochemical performance. Additionally, Wang et al. demonstrated that Li-metal stability and polysulfide diffusion control were enhanced by [PP13]-based electrolytes [108,124]. According to their study, self-discharge was forbidden by the [PP13][TFSI]/1 M LiTFSI electrolyte. The capacity of Li+ to coordinate with Lewis acid cations is reduced by the weak Lewis acid/basic character of [PP13][TFSI], which is predicted to prevent the formation of Li deposits locally as well as regulate the mobility and solubility of Li2S x . The functioning of lithium sulfur batteries was examined by Ma et al. in relation to the addition of [Pyr14][TFSI] in the DOL(1,3-dioxolane)/DME(dimethyl ether)/LiTFSI electrolyte. The incorporation of [Pyr14][TFSI] may improve the battery's coulombic efficiency and cycle performance by slowing the polysulfide migration in the electrolyte and inhibiting their dissolution, which is caused by the poor donor ability of TFSI− (weak Lewis base) [52]. For the Li-S battery, Meisner et al. investigated Pyr14TFSI/DOL with varying LiTFSI concentrations. The 2.0 M LiTFSI Pyr14TFSI/DOL (2:1) had the best performance with an initial discharge capacity of 896 mAh g−1 and a CE of 98.1% for more than 200 cycles, as shown in Fig. 10 a [125]. To develop a novel IL-based electrolyte, Zhang et al. coupled high viscosity of [PP13][TFSI] with 1,2-dimethoxyethane's (DME) high lithium polysulfide solubility [127]. Because of the disparate physical and chemical characteristics between these two solvents, the diffusion and solubility rates of Li2S x are traded off in this electrolyte. By inhibiting internal shuttling, the combined [PP13][TFSI]/DME electrolyte gives the Li-S batteries a large capacity and good Coulombic efficiency. In the same year, Park and his associates prepared Li-S battery electrolytes [126] by dissolving Li[TFSA] in [DEME][TFSA] ionic liquid. Compared to cells using a traditional organic solvent electrolyte, the battery using electrolyte based on ILs demonstrated much higher coulombic efficiency and charge-discharge cycle stability (Fig. 10b). Lithium polysulfide (Li2S x ) dissolution was inhibited by the ILs-based electrolyte, which was responsible for the high cyclic stability of these batteries. When Peter et al. added LiNO3 to [C4mpyr][TFSI], they examined and contrasted the electrochemical performance and SEI layer of Li-S batteries with traditional ether electrolytes [128]. It was discovered that the LiNO3 addition to ILs prevented the polysulfide dissolution. In general, the combination of additives to ILs stops polysulfide from dissolving, increasing Li-S battery efficiency and lowering self-discharge considerably. Zuo et al. presented a stabilizer, [LiG3][TFSI] for Li10GeP2S12 (LGPS) and used this formulation to develop a solid state Li-S battery [129]. They verified that the LiG3 suppresses the shuttle effect by implementing a solid-liquid dual phase redox reaction, which improves the Li+ transport properties at the cathode/electrolyte interfaces. Compared to the LGPS electrolyte, the [LiG3][TFSI] electrolyte displayed a much greater capacity and significantly better cycle stability. 3.3 Lithium-oxygen batteries The theoretical specific energy of lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries is quite high (3458 Wh kg−1, Li2O2) [130], therefore, they have drawn a lot of interest. Advancement of Li-O2 batteries is halted by three primary issues. First off, the combination of combustible organic fluids is the electrolyte and oxygen is the cathode in Li-O2 batteries. This raises the possibility of an explosion or combustion of the battery. Second, the issue of drying out from electrolyte evaporation is also brought on by the battery's openness, which results in the reduction of long-term cycle capacity. Thirdly, the electrolyte would decompose due to the nucleophilic O2 − species that are produced when oxygen is electrochemically reduced with organic solvents [108,131]. Ionic liquids can help with the aforementioned problems in lithium-oxygen batteries owing to their low volatility, great stability against superoxide radicals, and non-flammability. Using the [PP13][TFSA], [DEME][TFSA], and [P14][TFSA] ILs as solvents for electrolytes, Nakamoto et al. compared their oxygen radical stability [132]. They found that in these electrolytes based on ILs, the rate-determining step is the oxygen supply for the synthesis of LiO x . Of these electrolyte systems based on ILs, the [DEME][TFSA] IL continued to exhibit the largest activity for LiO x production. When compared to [PP13][TFSA], Higashi et al. [133] discovered that the electrode's discharge capacity (4315 mAh g−1, at 0.1 mA cm−2 current density) was substantially enhanced by the [DEME][TFSA]-based electrolyte (Fig. 11 a). Lithium-oxygen batteries were reported by Elia et al. utilizing [Pyr14][TFSI] ionic liquid combined with a LiTFSI salt solution in poly(ethylene glycol)500-dimethylether (PEG500DME) as the electrolyte. By stabilizing the intermediate O2 − and lowering parasitic side reactions, the ionic liquid's big cations can boost the Li-O2 battery's capacity and cycle life [134]. Another interesting electrolytic solvent for Li-O2 batteries is imidazolium-based IL electrolytes. A unique [Bmim][TFSI] IL composite electrolyte was synthesized by Cai and colleagues, and it was effectively used in the Li-O2 battery [135]. The battery shows a specific capacity of 1300 mAh g−1 at its discharge plateau of about 2.5 V for the first discharge, and a long-term operation could reach 1800 h for 10 times cycle. Their findings indicated that the Li-O2 battery has high cycle stability and capacity and further suggested that an electrolyte based on [Bmim][TFSI] IL could be anticipated to work better in a Li-O2 battery. A novel polymeric ionic liquid-based hybrid electrolyte, formed from LiFSI as the salt and a mixture of tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether and polymeric ionic liquid of P[C5O2NMA,11]FSI as the solvent, was recently devised by Liu et al. to improve cycle life and reversibility (O2 recovery efficiency of 94.4%). This was caused by the ionic liquid mixed electrolyte's high O2 solubility and improved oxidation resistance, which helped the cathode's reversible oxygen electrochemistry [136]. Specifically, this new electrolyte, when in contact with lithium metal anodes, has the ability to produce a uniform SEI with high ionic conductivity for Li+ transport and desired mechanical property for suppression of dendritic lithium growth. ILs offer promising safety and performance enhancements for lithium-based batteries due to their non-flammability, high thermal stability, and wide electrochemical windows. However, their high viscosity and high cost pose significant challenges. For LIBs, ILs improve thermal stability, suppress dendrite growth, and enhance cycling performance, yet issues like low conductivity and electrolyte compatibility persist. For Li-S batteries, ILs mitigate the shuttle effect and enhance polysulfide solubility, but challenges include controlling viscosity and optimizing the electrolyte's physical-chemical balance. Similarly, Li-O2 batteries benefit from ILs' stability against oxygen radicals and non-volatility, though cycle life and electrode stability need improvement. Future efforts should focus on developing hybrid IL electrolytes with tailored viscosities, advanced additives to stabilize SEI layers, and cost-effective, scalable IL production methods. Research into task-specific ILs and combinations with organic or solid-state systems is key to addressing performance constraints while ensuring long-term stability and commercial viability. 4 Applications of DESs in lithium batteries Li-ion and Li-metal batteries Since their initial commercial use in the 1990s, LIBs have shown themselves to be a game-changing technology [137]. They are distinguished by many appealing traits for energy storage, which includes extended shelf life, minimal self-discharge, high energy density, and good rate capacity [28,138]. It is necessary to provide inexpensive electrolytes with good thermal stability, low flammability, and high ionic conductivity because using volatile and flammable organic liquid electrolytes raises major safety issues, for example the possibility of explosion and fire in harsh situations (e.g., overcharging, clash, and overheating) [139]. The eutectic combination of LiX salts (X = TFSI−, ClO4 −, PF6 −, or other anions) with HBDs like urea, [140] Ace, [91,141], and NMAc [84,88], are therefore being researched as electrolytes for non-aqueous LIBs. LiTFSI/NMAc DES electrolytes' physical and chemical characteristics were examined by Boisset et al., who also assessed the electrochemical performance of these electrolytes for LIBs and supercapacitors [88]. The conductivity of the LiTFSI/NMAc (1:4 M ratio) electrolyte at room temperature (RT) was about 1.61 mS cm−1. The ionic conductivity increases to 28.4 mS cm−1 at temperature up to 150 °C (Fig. 12 a). The DES can retain a liquid phase at temperatures ranging from −72 to 240 °C, allowing it to be used in low-temperature applications. For 80 cycles at 80 °C, the cell produced nearly no capacity degradation when utilized in a LiFePO4 (LFP)||Li battery (Fig. 12b). These findings demonstrate that this DES's superior thermal stability, safety, and superionic nature at high temperatures make it a highly advantageous electrolyte. Three DES electrolytes with various Li salts were later studied by the same team [84]. The greater binding energy of TFSI− to metal ions makes it easier for LiTFSI salt to form a DES than LiPF6 and LiNO3. Additionally, compared to LiPF6/NMAc and LiNO3/NMAc, the LiTFSI/NMAc combination exhibits a reduced viscosity, which speeds up ion transport. In a subsequent work, DES was created using a combination of LiTFSI and 2,2,2-trifluoroacetamide (TFA). After evaluation, the DESs demonstrated good electrochemical characteristics, ionic conductivity (1.5 mS cm−1 at 30 °C), thermal stability (up to 150 °C) and quite large electrochemical stability window up to 4.9–5.3 V (vs. Li/Li+). The findings demonstrated that when DESs were diluted with a little amount of ethylene carbonate (EC), they displayed advantageous qualities and may be utilized in Li-ion batteries. According to the findings of the tests conducted on the Li anode and the LiMn2O4 cathode, the LiTFSI:TFA (4:1) electrolyte solution with an extra 10% EC (DES) exhibited a consistent cycle behavior for 50 cycles and produced outstanding results with a capacity of 102 mAh g−1 [142]. Research on pristine DESs is obviously essential, but dissolution of Li salts must be taken into account if these media are to be used in electrochemical applications like LIBs. As a result, an initial comprehension of how the DES organization hierarchy changes when the salt is added is required. Reline has been investigated as the prototypical DES when the same anion is present in the Li salt, LiCl [145,146]. Abbott et al. earlier noted that LiCl was highly soluble in reline (>2.5 mol dm−3) [70]. The dynamic viscosity rises exponentially and the density of reline applied with LiCl rises linearly as the LiCl concentration rises. ChCl mixtures containing several HBDs including EG (ethylene glycol), G (glycol), and LA (lactic acid) were also examined when a Li salt (LiTFSI, LiPF6) was added. The nano/microstructural arrangement of the pure DESs is considerably disturbed by the addition of salt. In general, the Li salt results in a drop in 1H diffusion values, reduction in conductivity and a rise in viscosity. According to earlier findings, EG-based systems outperformed G or LA-based systems in terms of conductivities, diffusivities, and viscosities. This was because there was a smaller network of hydrogen bonds between ChCl and EG as well as among EG molecules [143,147]. Li salts comprising ChCl:EG may thus function as a separate medium for electrochemical processes. Specifically, ChCl:EG + 0.5 M LiPF6 demonstrated a room temperature viscosity of 88.4 mPa s and an ionic conductivity of 7.95 mS cm−1, as well as respectable electrochemical stability of 3.5 V against glassy carbon as the working electrode (Fig. 12c) [143]. It would be preferable to include DESs into the polymer matrix to construct nonhazardous and leak-free LIBs, even if liquid DESs are thought of as “green” solvents in LIBs. Logan and colleagues described a novel family of highly efficient, safe gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs) that include a LiTFSI/NMAc DES and UV-cured acrylic polymers [148]. Compared to the liquid DESs, the eutectic GPEs showed better electrochemical stability, yet, they still require improvement in terms of rate performance. It should be noted that because of the polymer matrix, eutectic GPEs exhibit far greater nonflammability than liquid DESs. The LiMn2O4 (LMO)||Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) complete cell containing eutectic GPE demonstrated significantly improved cyclic stability, retaining 60% of its capacity after 200 cycles with the addition of 1.5 wt% water to the eutectic GPE and pure DES. As a novel type of solid composite electrolytes, eutectogels were designed by Joos et al. with the DES contained within a silica matrix [149]. A nonaqueous sol-gel method was used to create the clear, uniform, glass-like eutectogel monoliths. An ionic conductivity of about 1.5 mS cm−1 was observed in the optimized eutectogel electrolyte at 25 °C and the capacity of 105 mAh g−1 was given by the resulting LFP||eutectogel electrolyte||Li cell at 0.1 C. Furthermore, high energy–density aqueous LIBs have also been employed using the DES electrolyte. A novel DES was created by Jiang et al. using water, lithium perchlorate (LiClO4), and methylsulfonylmethane (MSM) (Fig. 12d) [144]. With water amounts ranging from 0.3 to 1 in the molar ratio, the mixes show a stable liquid phase when the MSM/LiClO4 molar ratios are kept between 2 and 3. The resulting DES electrolyte has a broad ESW of around 3.5 V (vs. SHE) and is inexpensive, safe, and ecologically benign. The ionic conductivity of the electrochemically stable DES (MSM:LiClO4:H2O = 1.8:1:1) was high, 3.87 mS cm−1. At a high current of 4.5 C, a 72.2% capacity retention after 1000 cycles was attained when utilized as the electrolyte to create an LMO||LTO aqueous LIB. Since Li metal has a far higher specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and a much lower electrode potential (−3.04 V) than standard hydrogen electrodes (SHE), hence it is the perfect anode for Li batteries [151,152]. However, unstable SEI and unpredictable dendritic development have hindered the usage of Li metal anode in practice, resulting in rapid capacity fading, low Coulombic efficiency (CE), possibly catastrophic safety hazards. To stop Li dendritic development, many eutectic electrolytes for Li metal anodes have been developed [153,154]. Cui et al., for instance, described that for Li metal batteries, dual-anion DES based on succinonitrile (SN) is a highly safe electrolyte [154]. At 25 °C, the SN-based DES has a significant Li+ transfer number of 0.44 and a high ionic conductivity of 2.86 mS cm−1, indicating strong interfacial compatibility with Li metal. Contrary to the traditional carbonate electrolyte, DES electrolyte based on SN also demonstrated nonflammability and very little weight loss at 150 °C. At a cut-off voltage of 3.0–4.7 V, the newly prepared DES has demonstrated remarkable cycling stability and retention capacity of around 70% for 500 cycles when used with high-voltage LiCoO2||Li batteries. When compared to the conventional 1 M LiPF6-EC/DMC electrolyte cell (which has low capacity after 150 cycles), it is far superior. Despite thorough assessments, the LiCoO2||Li pouch cells were able to continuously power an LED, suggesting the great efficiency of the SN-based DES electrolytes. With the addition of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) to a eutectic combination of LiTFSI and NMAc, Zhou and colleagues recently thermally polymerized 2-(3-(6-methyl-4-oxo-1,4-dihydropyrimidin-2-yl)ureido)ethyl methacrylate and pentaerythritol tetraacrylate monomers to create a DES-based polymer (DSP) electrolyte [150]. In addition to improve the polymer electrolyte's ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability, the FEC notably facilitates the development of stable interfaces at the anode and cathode, which inhibits the growth of Li dendrites on the anode side and structural degradation on the cathode side. Moreover, the dissolution of Mn2+ from the lithium transition metal oxide cathode is suppressed and the Li-ion flow is controlled by the self-healing polymer matrix (Fig. 13 a). The Li||Li and Li||Cu test results showed that the DSP electrolyte encouraged high plating/stripping CEs and homogeneous Li deposition. Unlike the LMO||DES electrolyte||Li cell, which failed after 80 cycles, the polymer electrolyte-equipped cell retained 86.1% of its capacity after 200 cycles, maintaining a reversible capacity of 99.5 mA h g−1, as shown in Figure (Fig. 13b). A novel, low-cost eutectogel membrane based on DES immobilized poly (vinylidene fluoride-hexafluoro propylene) (PVDF-HFP) was proposed as a solid electrolyte by Li and colleagues for safe lithium metal batteries [155].
