The DES was prepared by mixing the NMAc and LiTFSI in a molar ratio of 4:1. The eutectogel was formed by incorporating 70 wt% DES into the PVDF-HFP, which was non-flammable and exhibited excellent mechanical properties. This eutectogel membrane electrolyte, with a thickness of about 25 μm, possessed an ionic conductivity of 3.05 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature and a wide electrochemical stability window (∼5 V vs. Li/Li+) which is also presented in Table 1. The Li//ETG//LFP battery maintained a capacity of 149.8 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C after 50 cycles. Sun et al. developed a novel supramolecular deep eutectic electrolyte based on synergistic interactions between Li–bonds and H–bonds through a combination of lithium salt (LiTFSI), acetamide (Ace) and boric acid (BA) [156]. The incorporation of BA served as an interface modification additive, functioning as both a Li–bonds acceptor and H–bonds donor/acceptor and enhanced the redox stability of the electrolyte, facilitated a solution phase discharge process and improved compatibility with the Li anode. The synthesized electrolyte demonstrated a high oxidation voltage of 4.5 V (vs. Li/Li+), an ultrahigh discharge capacity of 15225 mAh g−1 and stable cycling performance of 196 cycles in lithium-oxygen batteries. DESs show potential as safe and thermally stable electrolytes for lithium-ion and lithium-metal batteries, offering benefits like low flammability and low volatility. However, challenges include issues with Li salt dissolution, high viscosity, and unstable SEI formation in Li-metal anodes. Solutions like gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs) and eutectogels have improved safety and stability. Future work should focus on enhancing ionic conductivity, electrochemical stability, and addressing interfacial problems, while also improving cycling stability and rate performance for practical DES use in lithium batteries. A detailed comparative analysis of different thermophysical and electrotechnical properties of electrolytes consisting of ILs, DESs, and organic solvents is also presented in Table 1. 5 Challenges and future outlook Despite the enormous potential of ionic liquids and deep eutectic solvents for next-generation energy storage devices, a number of critical concerns need to be resolved before their full potential can be realized. Although IL-based electrolytes have several advantages, including low flammability, low vapor pressure, and great electrochemical stability but their high cost prevents them from being widely employed in energy storage systems [42]. Thus, it is crucial to design ILs that are many times less costly compared to those of the previous generation ILs while preserving the important qualities that make them desirable in energy applications [160]. The large organic cations and strong ion-pair interactions seen in most ILs also have a detrimental effect on conductivity, ion mobility, and the capacity to wet electrodes and separators. As a result, polarization and a rapid reduction in total electrochemical performance occur [161]. It has been shown that electrolytes based on ILs with high concentration of lithium salts can inhibit dendritic development and increase lithium mobility. However, too much salt can cause poor wettability and high viscosity, which prevents concentrated IL-based electrolytes from being widely used in energy storage. The idea of localized highly concentrated electrolyte (LHCE) was developed in order to overcome these difficulties [162]. By employing 1,1,2,2-tetrafuoroethyl 2,2,3,3-tetrafuoropropyl ether (HFE) as a diluent solvent and the LiFSI salt, N-methyl-N-propylpiperidinium bis(fuorosulfonyl)-imine (PP13FSI), Wang et al. created an LHCE based on ILs. The LHCE they developed has nonflammable properties and greater wettability on the separator when compared to existing electrolytes [163]. One important consideration in a hybrid electrolyte is the molar ratio of its constituent parts. The cycling performance of lithium symmetric cells is adversely affected when formulations containing a large amount of DMSO are used in the study of the LiTFSI in dimethyl sulfoxide 1-butyl-1-methylpyrrolidinium bis[(trifuoromethyl)sulfonyl] imide ((DMSO)-PYR14TFSI) hybrid electrolyte. This deterioration results from the Li metal reaction with DMSO solvent. However, the elevated Li salt concentrations in IL may cause difficulties such as decreased ionic mobility and increased viscosity [164]. A number of variables, including the organic solvents, Li salts and the kinds of ILs, along with the ratios of the constituents and the temperature at which they are applied, all affect the hybrid electrolytes' electrochemical performance. Therefore, care should be taken while choosing IL-based hybrid electrolytes, keeping in mind the particular usage circumstances in which they will be used [42]. The thorough examination of the connection between ILs and device performance is necessary for future advancement. The detailed interaction mechanisms between the device's electrode materials and the ILs continue to require a thorough knowledge in order to achieve the intended commercial use and further increase the usage efficiency. It is anticipated that further intriguing studies will provide low viscosity, low-cost electrolytes based on IL with superior performance even at low-temperature, together with battery electrode materials to get around the restrictions and completely investigate the possible uses of IL-based electrolytes [165]. On the other hand, multitude of unique features makes DESs suitable for use in a number of applications. Nevertheless, a number of obstacles have prevented DESs from being widely used in electrochemical applications [166]. The performance of DESs in relation to the limited electrochemical window against alkali metals is one of the primary obstacles. Due to their instability on the reduction side, HBDs with NH bonds are most affected by the limited electrochemical window issue [22]. New HBDs that passivate the alkali metal surface without active bonding or functional additions need to be investigated in order to get around this problem. In order to uncover the influencing mechanism, theoretical simulations and ex situ or in situ/operando characterizations should be used to understand the physicochemical characteristics of DES electrolytes in lithium based batteries [167]. In certain applications, DESs may be challenging to handle and utilize due to their poor ionic conductivity and high viscosity at room temperature. In contrast to the advanced liquid organic electrolytes, these electrolytes might not be appropriate for usage at room temperature and might not function well at low temperatures. Overcoming this challenge there is a need to create of new DES systems with enhanced intermolecular interactions. This can be accomplished by investigating distinct HBA/HBD combinations with diverse functions and by adding functional additives to reduce the strength of HBA/HBD interactions. Moreover, slow kinetics and electrode compatibility are persistent issues, and plenty of batteries with DES electrolyte don't have enough capacity. Although energy storage systems based on DES have the ability to save money and improve the environment, much more work has to be done before they can be made commercially available. Researchers have improved the characteristics of DESs for use in electrochemical applications despite these obstacles. To employ them in a greater variety of reactions and tests, for instance, scientists have created new DES formulations with a broader electrochemical window. A DES's unique physicochemical features may be combined with polymers' strong mechanical qualities to create ecologically benign materials, which make the idea of DES incorporation in a polymer matrix, an intriguing one. Finally, the idea of creating combinations with numerous components is really fascinating. Ternary and quaternary DESs have not yet been thoroughly investigated, despite a few reports of them. The viscosity, density, electrochemical stability window and conductivity of DESs can all be enhanced by adding another cosolvent or water to the DESs. It might even give them antifreeze and flame-resistant qualities. There are still a lot of unanswered questions with DESs, and further study is required in many areas. For instance, additional study is still required to understand the possible health and environmental effects of DESs, despite the fact that they are usually thought to be less harmful and more biodegradable than conventional solvents. This covers research on DESs' toxicity, persistence, and biodegradability in the environment as well as their capacity to build up in living things [28]. Furthermore, information about how well DESs function in a variety of settings and applications is still required. In conclusion, ILs and DESs hold great promise for energy storage but face challenges like high costs, viscosity, and limited electrochemical stability. Advances in IL formulations and DES modifications, such as new HBA/HBD combinations and hybrid systems, show potential for overcoming these barriers. However, further research is needed to enhance their performance, environmental compatibility, and scalability. Addressing these gaps will enable their broader adoption in energy storage technologies. 6 Conclusions The study of DESs and ILs for energy storage devices specifically in lithium batteries demonstrates their enormous potential as revolutionary electrolytes. Both DESs and ILs have unique benefits that help in overcoming some of the drawbacks of traditional organic solvents, especially when it comes to their broad electrochemical windows, non-volatility, and thermal stability. This review highlighted the recent progress of ILs and DESs, particularly in rechargeable lithium-based batteries like Li-ion batteries, Li-O2 batteries, and Li-S batteries. It is observed that ILs perform effectively in applications which demand for long-term cycle performance, wide electrochemical stability, and high ionic conductivity. They are extremely versatile for a range of battery chemistries, including lithium-ion and others, due to their adjustable nature, which permits fine control over physicochemical parameters. Large-scale implementation is hampered by the frequently high synthesis costs and environmental issues related to some ILs. The issue might be resolved by investigating novel synthetic techniques and increasing the production scale. In contrast, DESs emerge as a cost-effective, environmentally friendly alternative, offering easier preparation and lower toxicity. In some energy storage systems where safety, environmental effect, and material cost are crucial considerations, DESs have demonstrated significant potential despite having greater viscosities and lower ionic conductivities. By adding additives like water and carefully choosing the donors and acceptors for hydrogen bonds, these characteristics may be enhanced. The adaptability of DESs to different salts and compositions also opens avenues for enhancing electrochemical performance. For DESs and ILs to achieve widespread adoption, more study is required to fully comprehend their environmental impact, safety, and long-term effects on human health. Their complementary qualities suggest that ILs and DESs can be tailored for specific applications, from high-performance batteries to more economical, sustainable solutions. The high energy density and safety performance of energy storage devices are becoming increasingly important, which means that DESs and ILs have a wide range of possible applications. The future of DESs and ILs in energy storage applications is bright, and they will probably become more significant in the creation of advanced energy storage systems and other electrochemical technologies that are more ecologically friendly and sustainable. coredata.dc:description: The rising need for efficient and sustainable energy storage systems has led to increased interest in the use of advanced electrolytes consisting of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) and ionic liquids (ILs). These electrolytes are appealing candidates for supercapacitors, next-generation lithium-ion batteries, and different energy storage systems because of their special features including non-flammability, low volatility, low-toxicity, good electrochemical stability, and good thermal and chemical stability. This review explores the advantages of the proposed electrolytes by examining their potential to address the critical challenges in lithium battery technology, including safety concerns, energy density limitations, and operational stability. To achieve this, a comprehensive overview of the lithium salts commonly employed in rechargeable lithium battery electrolytes is presented. Moreover, key physicochemical and functional attributes of ILs and DESs, such as electrochemical stability, ionic conductivity, nonflammability, and viscosity are also discussed with a focus on how these features impact battery performance. The integration of lithium salts with ILs and DESs in modern lithium battery technologies, including lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries, lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries, and lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, are further examined in the study. Various electrochemical performance metrics including cycling stability, charge/discharge profiles, retention capacity and battery’s coulombic efficiency (CE) are also analyzed for the above-mentioned systems. By summarizing recent advances and challenges, this review also highlights the potential of electrolytes consisting of DESs and ILs to enhance energy density, durability, and safety in future energy storage applications. Additionally future research directions, including the molecular optimization of ILs and DESs, optimizing lithium salt compositions, and developing scalable synthesis methods to accelerate their practical implementation in next-generation energy storage applications are also explored.
